question: Question_B_04_(d)
statement:
Let a={[}1,2,-1{]}. Consider the transformation
$T:\mathbb{R}^3\to\mathbb{R}^3$ defined by
$T(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a}$ for all \textbf{x} in
$\mathbb{R}^3$, where $\times$ is the cross-product in $\mathbb{R}^3$.

Find \emph{any} nonzero vector \textbf{x} such that
T(\textbf{x})=\textbf{0}.
sols:
In
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B4_(b)}{part(b)},
we have that

\begin{align*}A=
\begin{bmatrix}
0  &  -1  &  -2\\
1  &  0   &  1\\
2  &  -1  &  0
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

and in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B4_(c)}{part(c)}
we concluded that det(A)=0. Therefore A has a null space and there are
many solutions such that A\textbf{x}=\textbf{0}. We could perform some
sort of Gaussian elimination and determine the entire null-space but the
question asks for \textbf{any} vector and so we are permitted to just
guess. In fact we saw in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B4_(c)}{part(c)}
that any vector parallel to \textbf{a} had a zero cross product.
Therefore $T(\mathbf{a})=\mathbf{a}\times\mathbf{a}=\mathbf{0}$.

''Note that, since \emph{T(\textbf{a}) = A\textbf{a}} we can also verify
this using the matrix representation:

\begin{align*}\begin{bmatrix}
0  &  -1  &  -2\\
1  &  0   &  1\\
2  &  -1  &  0
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}.\end{align*}

Therefore a vector such that T(\textbf{x})=\textbf{0} is
\textbf{x}=\textbf{a} (or any vector of the form \emph{k\textbf{a}}, due
to the linearity of \emph{T}).
hints: Do we know anything about cross-products that produce the zero vector?
